THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
of  up  to  CNY150,000,000.00  to  Tedahang  Cold  Chain  Logistics  for  the  Tianjin  Cold  Chain 
Logistics Facility Development Project in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

 
A. 
 

Project Identification and Description 

1. 

Project Identification 

 
Along  with  the  rapid  economic  growth  in  the  PRC  came  a  significant  increase  in  the 
2. 
demand for fresh produce and a wider range of meat and fish products. According to the China 
Federation  of  Logistics  and  Purchasing  in  2007,  demand  for  logistics  service  in  the  PRC  had 
reached  CNY75.2  billion,  a  year-on-year  increase  of  26.2%;  and  cargo  volume  reached 
22.53 billion  tons,  a  year-on-year  increase  of  10.7%. 1 However,  because  of  lack  of  proper 
infrastructure, food is transported and stored  without a controlled environment—shortening the 
shelf  life  and  resulting  in  higher  spoilage  rates.  This  has  significantly  increased  demand  for 
refrigerated or cold chain logistics.  
 
3. 
A cold chain is a temperature-controlled supply chain that forms a critical element in an 
uninterrupted  series  of  storage  and  distribution  activities.  It  helps  ensure  the  shelf  life  of 
products  such  as  fresh  agricultural  produce,  frozen  food,  photographic  film,  chemicals,  and 
pharmaceutical  drugs.  This  process  is  preferred  because  of  its  ability  to  prolong  the  quality  of 
perishable goods. Throughout the process of production, storage, transportation, and delivery to 
the  consumer,  these  products  must  be  maintained  in  a  low  temperature  environment  to 
preserve their quality. In developed countries such as Australia, Canada, and the United States 
(US),  a seamless  cold chain  logistics  system for  agricultural  products  is a fundamental  part of 
logistics  infrastructure  and  the  cold  chain  network  has  average  coverage  of  80%–100%  of the 
market.  In  the  US,  frozen  food  transport  amounts  to  20  million  tons  annually,  encompassing 
almost  3,000  varieties  of  products,  and  equates  to  per  capita  consumption  of  almost 
60 kilograms. 
 
4. 
If approved, the project will be the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) first intervention 
in logistics in the PRC.2 Cold chain logistics is a relatively nascent  industry in the PRC, so the 
proposed  intervention  from  ADB  will  highlight  the  importance  of  logistics  in  relation  to  food 
safety. This is in line with the Food Safety Law, 2009, which establishes and improves the food 
safety management system and adopts efficient management measures to ensure food safety 
in  the  PRC.  It  is  also  in  line  with  the  12th  Five-Year  Plan,  2011–2015,  which  calls  for  the 
development of a modern logistics industry in the PRC.3 The facility can be used as a model for 
best  practices

management, and trading systems. ADB can leverage the project to higher-level dialogue with 
the  Government  of  the  PRC  to  develop  optimal  health,  sanitary,  and  phytosanitary  inspection 
protocols for refrigerated freight.

The  project  will  also play  a positive role  in  supporting regional  cooperation,  particularly 
5. 
between  the  PRC  and  Mongolia.  ADB  supports  PRC–Mongolia  cooperation  under  the  broad 
framework and as an integral part of the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) 
program.  One  of  the  key  objectives  of  PRC–Mongolia  cooperation  in  transport  and  trade 
facilitation  areas  is  to  improve  Mongolia’s  access  to  international  markets.  As  a  landlocked 
country, Mongolia relies on the PRC for the nearest sea access. Tianjin, which is located at the 
south  end  of  the  CAREC  transport  corridor  4b  linking  Mongolia  and  the  PRC,  has  since  the 
1990s served as the only seaport for bulk of Mongolia’s international trade based on a bilateral 
agreement  signed  in  1991.  As  part  of  the  assistance  to  PRC–Mongolia  cooperation  in  trade 
facilitation,  ADB  has  been  making  efforts  to  improve  ties  between  Mongolia’s  foreign  trade 
communities and their counterparts in Tianjin.4 The enhanced capacity in cold chain logistics in 
Tianjin to be realized under the project will help provide better services to Mongolia’s export of 
agricultural produce, particularly meat and dairy products. 
 
6. 
Tianjin  Binhai  TEDA  Logistics  Group  (TBTL)  is  a  leading  logistics  service  provider  in 
Tianjin, which is a key port in the northeastern seaboard.5 TBTL is 70% owned by the state6 and 
30% listed on the Growth Enterprise Market of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. TBTL is active 
in a number of logistics areas through wholly- or majority-owned subsidiaries, such as container 
yard operation, bulk commodities (steel alloys in particular), logistics for Toyota automobiles and 
parts,  as  well  as  short-term  financing  services  for  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises.  Cold 
chain  logistics  presents  a  new  opportunity  for  TBTL  to  fulfill  an  opportunity  in  the  market  and 
address the lack of facilities and services in Tianjin Binhai New Area.

venture,  the  project  will  lead  to  additional  development  impacts  through  private  sector 
participation in a new industry, policy dialogue, and improved trade facilitation.

Project Design 

 
8. 
TBTL  is  allocating  existing  resources  to  explore  new  businesses  and  diversification  of 
revenue sources. It purchased 9 hectares (ha) of land in 2007 and 8 ha in 2009 in the Tianjin 
port  area.  After  detailed  market  research  and  consultation  with  Tianjin  Commodity  Inspection 
Bureau  and  other  government  departments,  TBTL  determined  that  the  cold  chain  logistics 
market would be a suitable new venture. Tianjin port has no cold storage, customs inspection, 
or special inspection facilities—providing a compelling opportunity for a third-party operator. The 
land  purchased  is  intended for frozen food  warehouses and as  a  location for related  customs, 
health, and phytosanitary inspections.  
 
9. 
Tedahang Cold Chain Logistics (TCCL) is a joint venture project company among TBTL, 
Toyota  Tsusho,  and  Kamigumi  focused  on  the  cold  chain  logistics  business.  For  TBTL,  TCCL 
will be a market entry point to the cold chain logistics industry. The project will enable TBTL to 
capture the rapid growth in logistics, while serving as a model for the development of the cold

Located  in  Tianjin  Port  Container  Logistics  Center,  the  site  will  have  a  large-capacity 
10. 
cold  storage  facility—including  merchandise  handling,  warehousing,  logistics  equipment,  and 
inspection facility—combined with a customs inspection service facility for fruits and vegetables, 
meat, and aquatic products. Three cold storage warehouses and affiliated facilities will be built 
at  a  total  cost  of  CNY600  million.  The  cold  storage  houses  will  have  various  temperature 
zones—from a deep cold of –50°C for seafood to below –20°C for most meats and above 0°C 
for vegetables, fruits, and flowers. The facility will cover about 8 ha, including the main function 
buildings;  housing  customs  inspection  facility  for  large  cold  storage  shipments;  refrigerated 
container yard; and logistics, office, and supporting ancillary facilities.

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 and Country Strategy 

 
17. 
The  project  is  consistent  with  Strategy  2020  in  terms  of  inclusive  economic  growth  in 
developing  and  expanding  economic  activities  by  increasing  access  to  new  markets  for 
agricultural  products. 7  The  project  is  also  consistent  with  two  of  the  five  core  areas  of 
operational  focus  identified:  infrastructure  and  regional  cooperation  and  integration.  ADB’s 
intervention in the project aims to (i) increase policy dialogue; (ii) encourage the participation of 
private  capital  for  developing  the  refrigerated  supply-chain  and  logistics  infrastructure  facility 
that will bring in state-of-the-art technology, know-how, and processes, with benefits in material-
handling  capacity  and  improved  energy  efficiency;  and  (iii)  facilitate  Mongolia’s  international 
trade of agriculture products. Additionally, development of the facility will foster improvements in 
transportation  logistics  and  customs  management,  leading  to  more  efficient  traffic,  facilitating 
trade of frozen produce, reducing transit cost, and fostering increased trade.  
 
18. 
The  project  is  in  line  with  the  PRC  country  partnership  strategy,  2011–2015  through 
pillar  1:  inclusive  growth,  seeking  to  foster  a  balanced  and  equitable  development,  including 
lending  activities  in  regional  and  subregional  infrastructure  projects.8 Furthermore,  the  project 
will address transport connectivity and trade facilitation to promote transport and trade activities 
along economic corridors, (in particular CAREC Corridor 4b), one of the drivers of change. The 
development  of  the  refrigerated  supply-chain  and  logistics  facility  will  reduce  spoilage  and 
increase the value of agricultural produce.

2. 

Lessons from Previous Operations 

 
20. 
In  terms  of  food  safety,  ADB  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  the  National  Food  Safety 
Regulatory  and Strategic  Framework  was implemented to  help strengthen  the  State  Food  and 
Drug  Administration  through  formulation  of  a  comprehensive  framework  covering  food  safety 
policies,  laws  and  regulations,  and  standards,  as  well  as  cross-agency  coordination  to  ensure 
their  effective implementation. The TA  recommendation for reforms  was  communicated  in two 
core  areas—institutional  reform 
improved  coordination—and  has 
for  streamlining  and 
contributed  to  the  draft  Food  Safety  Law,  which  is  a  substantial  improvement  from  previously 
fragmented legislation, and a meaningful step toward a comprehensive legal framework.10 
 
21. 
Current  ADB  operations  in  logistics  and trade facilitation include the  Regional  Logistics 
Development  Project  in  Mongolia, 11  which  will  be  implemented  in  Zamyn  Uud  to  promote 
economic growth necessary to reduce rural poverty resulting from inadequate transport services 
and  high costs.  Logistics  development  in  Zamyn Uud  is  part  of the  program for  the  integrated 
development  of  a free  economic zone in this  poor region,  which  shares borders  with the  PRC 
and is the main gateway for Mongolia’s trade with the PRC and other parts of the world. 
 
Another  intervention  is  the  Customs  Modernization  Project, 12  which  aims  to  finance 
22. 
(i) the  establishment  of  the  Mongolian  customs  automated  information  system;  (ii)  the 
improvement  of  infrastructure  at  major  customs  houses  and  customs  border  posts;  and 
(iii) institutional  strengthening,  including  business  process  reengineering,  capacity  building  in 
relation  to  the  above  two  components,  interagency  coordination,  regional  cooperation,  and 
public–private  partnerships.  The  expected  impact  is  increased  volume  and  efficiency  of 
Mongolia’s international trade.  
  
23. 
These  ADB  interventions  will  form  the  foundation  for  the  development  of  the  proposed 
project, which will complement the Zamyn Uud Project by facilitating transportation of Mongolian 
products requiring a temperature-controlled environment and facilitate trade in new markets. In 
food safety, the project will contribute to establishing a platform for proper storage of perishable 
goods. The lessons learned from previous operations include the importance that needs to be 
attributed  to  (i)  rigorous  analysis  of  the  transaction  financials,  including  stress  testing  of  the 
demand projections to factor in potential market disruptions; (ii)  a clear review of the sponsors 
involved in the transaction; and (iii) clear awareness of the parties involved.

TCCL is set up by TBTL as a joint venture project company in cooperation with 
Kamigumi and Toyota. TBTL will retain a majority stake in TCCL and will retain (i) 
control over management policy; (ii) budget, financial, and accounting procedures; 
and (iii) control of the board, and major project board resolutions. TBTL, Toyota, and 
Kamigumi will appoint key management positions (e.g., general manager, financial 
controller, and chief engineer) depending on each shareholder’s expertise. 

Q4 2012–Q4 2013 

The engineering, procurement and construction contract was awarded on 6 July 2011 
to China Railway Construction 18th Bureau Group. The specifications of the contract 
include the construction of the Cold Storage Warehouse No. 1 with an area of 
28,974.07 m2; 3,801.71 m2 of cargo handling space; and 1,433.60 m2 of refrigeration 
room and transformer room, situated at Tianjin Port Container Logistics Center.  
The revenue stream is based on three major areas: storage, transport, and 
inspection. For all goods coming into the inspection process, fees are charged for 
transport in and out of the compound, storage, loading and unloading, as well as 
value-added services such as sorting, labeling, and plastic wrapping. The fee 
structure is based on market standards and reflects full cost recovery of the 
operational expenditures. 
The cost structure is straightforward for the cold storage operations. Aside from staff 
costs (42.5% of total operational cost), electricity is the primary source of expenditure 
(21.2%). Other costs include water supply, drainage, and heating but account for less 
than 1% of the total operational cost. 
TCCL will submit to ADB quarterly unaudited financial statements, annual audited 
financial statements, and environmental and social monitoring reports. The indicators 
are in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1).

27. 
TBTL saw  in  ADB  not  just  a  source  of financing for  a  relatively  nascent  industry  in the 
PRC but more importantly, an alliance in creating high standards for logistics as well as setting 
the  policy  framework  at  the  central  level.  ADB  has  assisted  the  central  government  in 
strengthening the national food safety regulatory and strategic framework through TA approved 
in  2004  and  completed  in  2007,  whereby  high-level  meetings  have  been  conducted  to  help 
develop  more  consistent  regulation  for  food  safety  (footnote  10).  TBTL  sees  ADB’s  access  to 
the central government as an invaluable asset in promoting the establishment of benchmarks on 
logistics handling and quality control. 
 
28. 

Furthermore, ADB’s participation in the project will add substantial value in the following: 

Facilitating  dialogue  for  regional  trade  facilitation  and  integration  of  the  logistics 
network between the PRC and Mongolia and under the broader framework of the 
CAREC. 
Encouraging  the  adoption  of  a  structured  framework  to  manage  social  and 
environmental  safeguard  concerns,  which  may  become  the  benchmark  for  the 
sector in the PRC. 
Enhancing  best  practices  in  corporate  governance  of  TCCL  in  maintaining 
transparency and disclosure. 
Providing  financing  at  a  longer  tenure  to  ensure  a  proper  match  between  the 
project cash flows and the debt service obligations. 

Risks will include credit, market, regulatory, and operational risks. 

Guarantor  risk. The full guarantee of TBTL is crucial to the overall credit of the 
transaction,  making  it  essential  to  confirm  TBTL’s  capacity  as  guarantor.    Due 
diligence  confirmed  TBTL’s  capacity  to  implement  business  strategies  and  its 
historical  track  record  to  diversify  or  consolidate  businesses  to  preserve  its 
financial integrity.  However, it is critical for TBTL to retain their capacity to deliver 
on  their  full  and  unconditional  guarantee  on  the  project.  Covenants  in  the 
financing  documents  will  be  included  to  ensure  and  preserve  the  financial 
integrity of the guarantor over the life of the loan. 
 
Market  risk.    Due  diligence  covered  an  assessment  of  critical  factors  driving 
market  risk,  e.g.,  project  industry’s  barriers  to  entry;  uniqueness  of  TCCL’s 
service  to  the  customs  clearance  process;  key  drivers  for  revenue  generation; 
and  the  tariff  structure.    The  project’s  main  advantage  is  its  proximity  to  the 
Tianjin port, which serves 17 provinces with a population of over 600 million, and 
where  some  400,000  tons  of frozen meats  pass  through,  comprising  15%  of  all

Regulatory  risk.  Due diligence evaluated the level of government support and 
collaboration between TCCL and the Customs and the Inspection Bureau (CIQ).  
The  CIQ  and  other  relevant  government  agencies  demonstrated  significant 
support for this project, which is in line with national development and food safety 
priorities. TCCL has also formed a symbiotic partnership with the CIQ in Tianjin, 
the  primary  government  agency  to  utilize  this  facility.  CIQ  deems  TCCL  as  an 
invaluable  partner  and  values  the  project  for  its  proximity  to  the  port  and  its 
contributions to increased efficiency of the inspection process. 

Operations and maintenance risk. The on-site presence of Toyota Tsusho and 
Kamigumi  as  early  as  3  months  before  the  project’s  scheduled  commercial 
operations  indicates  that  both  sponsors,  equipped  with  cold  chain  and  systems 
management expertise, are taking active roles in project development. Kamigumi 
brings  substantial  expertise  in  cold  chain  management,  tested  and  proven 
through operational challenges experienced during the Kobe earthquake and the 
2011 tsunami in Japan.  Toyota Tsusho’s experience in systems management is 
also expected to be an asset to project operations.  To ensure continuous power 
availability,  the  project  is  connected  to  two  substations  within  the  Tianjin  port, 
including one substation that supports storage of highly sensitive chemicals and 
is considered a priority station in the event of power rationing.    

Completion  risk.  Construction of phase 1 is well under way, within budget, and 
expected  to  be  completed  by  Q3  2012.    Engineering,  procurement  and 
construction  (EPC)  requirements  for  phase  2  have  also  been  prepared  for 
tendering and construction will begin end 2012. Construction design took 2 years 
to complete and have been vetted by Japanese and European consultants while 
construction  and  technology  design  is  overseen  by  Kamigumi  and  Toyota 
Tsusho.  The  EPC  contractor  has  tested  capability  in  civil  works  with  an 
enforceable EPC contract under PRC regulation.

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

30. 
In  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009),  the  project  is  classified 
under category B for environment, category C for involuntary resettlement, and category C for 
indigenous  peoples.  The  project  is  located  in  an  industrial  and  logistics  zone  sited  far  from 
environmentally  sensitive  areas  and  receptors.  Environmental  impacts  mainly  involved  dust, 
noise,  and  vibration  generation  during  construction,  which  are  minimized 
through 
implementation of water sprinkling and cleaning system, use of low-noise powered mechanical 
equipment and hydraulic pile drivers. Domestic and construction solid wastes are collected and 
delivered  to  designated  off-site  disposal  locations.  During  operation,  the  risk  from  the  use  of 
ammonia  as  a  refrigerant  is  minimized  and  mitigated  as  fugitive  emissions  are  expected  to 
comply with the national ambient air quality standard and ammonia will be stored in appropriate 
cylinders  situated  in  restricted  entry  refrigerant  rooms.  An  explosive-proof  fan  and  ammonia 
detector will also be installed, emergency response procedures will be in place, and staff will be 
properly  trained  and  provided  with  personal  protective  equipment.  The  land  where  the  project 
will  be  constructed  covers  76,795.8  square meters  (m2)  and  is  under  the  name  of  TCCL.  The
